/**
 * Skincare & Acne Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const skincareGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'skincare',
  slug: 'skincare-acne',
  title: 'Skincare & Acne',
  subtitle: "Your skin is your face. Treat it right.",
  description: "Evidence-based skincare routines for clear, healthy skin. From basics to advanced treatments like tretinoin.",
  icon: 'Droplet',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 9,
  tags: ['skincare', 'acne', 'anti-aging', 'routine', 'tretinoin'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat', 'diet'],
  productIds: [
    'cerave_cleanser',
    'cerave_moisturizer',
    'sunscreen_elta',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'tretinoin_guide',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'skincare',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'skincare-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: '/guides/images/skincare-hero.jpg',
    alt: 'Clear, healthy skin transformation',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Basics of Good Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin is literally your face. It's the first thing people see, and it significantly impacts how attractive you appear.

**The Good News:**
- Skincare is not complicated
- Most improvements come from basics
- Results happen in weeks to months
- It's not expensive

**The Bad News:**
- Genetics play a role
- Some things take time
- There are no overnight fixes
- Consistency is required

**What Actually Works:**
1. Cleanser (clean skin)
2. Moisturizer (healthy barrier)
3. Sunscreen (prevent damage)
4. Tretinoin (for acne/anti-aging)

That's the core. Everything else is optimization.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-basics',
      title: 'The Basic Routine',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Start here. Master this before adding anything else.

**Morning Routine (2 minutes):**
1. Rinse face with water (or gentle cleanser if oily)
2. Apply moisturizer
3. Apply sunscreen (non-negotiable)

**Evening Routine (3 minutes):**
1. Cleanse face (remove dirt, oil, sunscreen)
2. Apply any actives (tretinoin, etc.)
3. Apply moisturizer

**That's It.**

Don't overcomplicate. Don't buy 10 products because TikTok said so. The basic routine done consistently beats a 12-step routine done sporadically.

**Order Matters:**
Thinnest to thickest consistency:
1. Cleansers (remove)
2. Toners/serums (watery actives)
3. Treatments (tretinoin, etc.)
4. Moisturizer (seal it in)
5. Sunscreen (protect from sun)`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
    },
    {
      id: 'cleansing',
      title: 'Cleansing: Do It Right',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most guys either skip cleansing or do it wrong.

**The Goal:**
Remove dirt, oil, sweat, and sunscreen without stripping your skin.

**How to Cleanse:**
1. Wet face with lukewarm water (not hot)
2. Apply dime-sized amount of cleanser
3. Massage gently for 30-60 seconds
4. Rinse thoroughly
5. Pat dry (don't rub)

**Choosing a Cleanser:**

| Skin Type | Cleanser Type |
|-----------|---------------|
| Oily/Acne | Foaming/gel cleanser |
| Normal | Either works |
| Dry/Sensitive | Cream/hydrating cleanser |

**Recommended:** CeraVe Foaming (oily) or CeraVe Hydrating (dry)

**Common Mistakes:**
1. Over-cleansing (2x daily max)
2. Hot water (damages barrier)
3. Harsh scrubs (causes irritation)
4. Not rinsing fully (leaves residue)
5. Rubbing with towel (causes friction)

**The Feel:**
After cleansing, skin should feel clean but not tight or squeaky. If it feels stripped, your cleanser is too harsh.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cleansing-technique',
          type: 'gif',
          url: '/guides/gifs/face-cleansing-technique.gif',
          alt: 'Proper face cleansing technique - gentle circular motions',
          caption: 'Gentle circular motions for 30-60 seconds',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'moisturizing',
      title: 'Moisturizing: Seal It In',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `A healthy skin barrier is the foundation of good skin.

**Why Moisturize:**
- Prevents water loss
- Repairs barrier function
- Reduces sensitivity
- Makes skin look healthier
- Required if using actives like tretinoin

**When:**
- Morning (after cleansing, before sunscreen)
- Evening (after actives or as last step)

**Choosing a Moisturizer:**

| Skin Type | Texture |
|-----------|---------|
| Oily | Lightweight/gel moisturizer |
| Normal | Lotion texture |
| Dry | Cream texture |

**Recommended:** CeraVe PM (lightweight), CeraVe Cream (thicker)

**Key Ingredients to Look For:**
- Ceramides (barrier repair)
- Hyaluronic acid (hydration)
- Niacinamide (reduces pores, calms skin)
- Glycerin (hydration)

**Application:**
- Apply to slightly damp skin for better absorption
- Use enough to cover face without being greasy
- Don't forget neck`,
      products: ['cerave_moisturizer'],
    },
    {
      id: 'sunscreen',
      title: 'Sunscreen: The Anti-Aging Essential',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Sun damage is the biggest scam your skin is running on your future self. Block it.

**The Reality:**
- 80% of visible skin aging is from sun exposure
- UV damage accumulates over years
- By the time you see damage, it's already been happening for a decade
- Sunscreen is the #1 anti-aging product

**The Protocol:**
- SPF 30 minimum, SPF 50 preferred
- Apply every morning (yes, even cloudy days)
- Reapply every 2 hours if outdoors
- About 1/4 teaspoon for face

**Choosing Sunscreen:**

**Chemical Sunscreens:**
- Absorbs into skin, absorbs UV rays
- More cosmetically elegant
- May sting eyes or irritate some skin
- Examples: Avobenzone, oxybenzone, octinoxate

**Mineral Sunscreens:**
- Sits on skin, reflects UV rays
- Can leave white cast
- Better for sensitive skin
- Examples: Zinc oxide, titanium dioxide

**Recommended:** EltaMD UV Clear SPF 46 (best for acne-prone skin)

**The Excuses (And Why They're Wrong):**
- "I don't burn" → UV damage happens regardless
- "I'm indoors" → UVA goes through windows
- "It's cloudy" → 80% of UV penetrates clouds
- "Sunscreen causes acne" → Get a better sunscreen`,
      products: ['sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Skipping sunscreen will undo your other skincare efforts',
        'Reapply if outdoors for extended periods'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'sunscreen-amount',
          type: 'image',
          url: '/guides/images/sunscreen-amount.jpg',
          alt: 'Proper sunscreen amount - 1/4 teaspoon for face',
          caption: 'Use about 1/4 teaspoon (two finger lengths) for your face',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'acne',
      title: 'Acne: Understanding and Treating',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Acne is the most common skin concern. Here's how to actually treat it.

**What Causes Acne:**
1. Excess sebum (oil) production
2. Dead skin cells clogging pores
3. Bacteria (C. acnes)
4. Inflammation

**Types of Acne:**
- **Comedonal:** Blackheads and whiteheads (clogged pores)
- **Inflammatory:** Red, swollen pimples
- **Cystic:** Deep, painful, scarring

**Treatment Hierarchy:**

**Level 1: Basic Routine**
- Consistent cleansing
- Non-comedogenic moisturizer
- Often fixes mild acne

**Level 2: Over-the-Counter Actives**
- Benzoyl peroxide (kills bacteria)
- Salicylic acid (unclogs pores)
- Adapalene/Differin (retinoid, OTC)

**Level 3: Prescription**
- Tretinoin (see next section)
- Antibiotics (temporary)
- Spironolactone (hormonal, for women)

**Level 4: Accutane/Isotretinoin**
- Nuclear option for severe or resistant acne
- 4-6 month course, usually permanent results
- Side effects but highly effective
- Requires dermatologist

**General Rules:**
- Be patient (6-12 weeks for actives to work)
- Don't pick (causes scarring)
- Change pillowcase frequently
- Clean phone screen`,
    },
    {
      id: 'tretinoin',
      title: 'Tretinoin: The Gold Standard',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Tretinoin (prescription retinoid) is the most evidence-backed skincare ingredient for both acne and anti-aging.

**What It Does:**
- Increases cell turnover
- Unclogs pores
- Reduces acne
- Fades dark spots
- Reduces fine lines
- Improves skin texture

**How to Get It:**
- Dermatologist prescription
- Online telemedicine (Curology, Apostrophe)
- Some countries: OTC

**Starting Protocol (Critical):**

**Week 1-2:** 2x per week only
**Week 3-4:** Every other night
**Week 5-6:** Every night (if tolerated)
**Ongoing:** Nightly, thin layer

**The Retinization Period:**
Expect 4-12 weeks of:
- Dryness
- Peeling
- Redness
- Possible purging (temporary increase in acne)

This is normal. Push through carefully. It gets better.

**Application Tips:**
1. Apply to completely dry skin (wait 20 min after washing)
2. Pea-sized amount for entire face
3. Avoid eye area initially
4. Follow with moisturizer
5. Use sunscreen daily (skin is more sensitive)

**Don't Use With:**
- Benzoyl peroxide (inactivates tret)
- Vitamin C (morning only)
- Other strong actives initially

**The Payoff:**
12-month mark is where the magic happens. Consistent tretinoin use genuinely reverses aging and transforms skin.`,
      products: ['tretinoin_guide', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Start low and slow—0.025% is enough initially',
        'Over-application causes more irritation, not faster results',
        'Tretinoin + sun exposure = damage. Always use sunscreen.'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-application',
          type: 'gif',
          url: '/guides/gifs/tretinoin-application.gif',
          alt: 'Proper tretinoin application - pea-sized amount',
          caption: 'Pea-sized amount, dot on forehead, cheeks, chin, then spread',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-timeline',
          type: 'image',
          url: '/guides/images/tretinoin-timeline.jpg',
          alt: 'Tretinoin results timeline - 3, 6, 12 month progress',
          caption: 'Expect 3-6 months for initial improvement, 12+ for full results',
          placement: 'full-width',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'skin-type',
      title: 'Know Your Skin Type',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin type determines product selection.

**Oily Skin:**
- Shiny by midday
- Visible pores
- Prone to acne
- Needs: Gel cleansers, lightweight moisturizers, mattifying products

**Dry Skin:**
- Feels tight
- Flaking or rough texture
- Fine lines more visible
- Needs: Cream cleansers, rich moisturizers, hydrating ingredients

**Combination Skin:**
- Oily T-zone (forehead, nose, chin)
- Dry cheeks
- Most common type
- Needs: Balanced approach, zone-specific treatment

**Sensitive Skin:**
- Reacts easily to products
- Redness, stinging
- Needs: Fragrance-free, minimal ingredients, patch testing

**Normal Skin:**
- Balanced
- Few issues
- Needs: Basic maintenance

**How to Test:**
1. Wash face, wait 30 minutes
2. Don't apply anything
3. Observe how skin feels and looks

If shiny → oily
If tight → dry
If both → combination
If irritated → sensitive
If fine → normal`,
    },
    {
      id: 'acne-scarring',
      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:

**Types of Acne Scars:**
- **Icepick:** Deep, narrow, V-shaped
- **Boxcar:** Wide, box-like depressions
- **Rolling:** Wave-like, uneven surface
- **Hyperpigmentation:** Dark marks (not true scars)

**What Actually Works:**

**For Hyperpigmentation (Dark Marks):**
- Time (fades naturally in 3-12 months)
- Tretinoin (speeds fading)
- Vitamin C (morning antioxidant)
- Niacinamide (in moisturizer)
- Sunscreen (prevents darkening)

**For True Scars (Texture):**
- Tretinoin (mild improvement over years)
- Microneedling (professional, 4-6 sessions)
- Chemical peels (professional, multiple sessions)
- Laser resurfacing (fractional CO2 or Fraxel)
- Subcision (for tethered scars)
- TCA Cross (for icepick scars)

**The Reality:**
- OTC products can't fix true textural scars
- Professional treatments are needed
- Multiple sessions required
- Results are improvement, not perfection
- Cost: $200-500+ per session

**Priority:**
1. Get acne under control first (stop creating new scars)
2. Wait for active breakouts to clear
3. Then address scarring`,
    },
    {
      id: 'lifestyle-factors',
      title: 'Lifestyle Factors for Clear Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your routine matters, but so does everything else:

**Sleep:**
- 7-9 hours for skin repair
- Poor sleep = inflammation = worse skin
- Sleep on clean pillowcases (change 2x/week)
- Silk pillowcase reduces friction

**Diet:**
- High glycemic foods may worsen acne
- Dairy is problematic for some people
- Stay hydrated (not magic, but helps)
- Omega-3s (anti-inflammatory)

**Stress:**
- Cortisol triggers oil production
- Stress acne is real
- Manage what you can

**Habits:**
- Don't touch your face
- Clean your phone
- Wash pillowcases
- Don't pick at skin
- Remove makeup before bed

**Gym:**
- Sweat can clog pores
- Wipe face during workout
- Shower/cleanse after
- Don't use dirty towels on face

**Sun:**
- Some sun can temporarily help acne
- But UV damage is worse long-term
- Use sunscreen anyway`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-by-goal',
      title: 'Routines by Goal',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:

**Goal: Basic Maintenance (No Issues)**
- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, moisturize

**Goal: Acne Control**
- AM: Cleanse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin (or benzoyl peroxide), moisturize

**Goal: Anti-Aging**
- AM: Cleanse, vitamin C serum, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin, moisturize

**Goal: Oily Skin Control**
- AM: Foaming cleanser, lightweight moisturizer, mattifying sunscreen
- PM: Foaming cleanser, niacinamide serum, lightweight moisturizer

**Goal: Sensitive Skin**
- AM: Water rinse, fragrance-free moisturizer, mineral sunscreen
- PM: Gentle cleanser, fragrance-free moisturizer
- Add actives very slowly

**Remember:**
Start with basics. Add one product at a time. Wait 2-4 weeks between additions. This lets you identify what works and what causes problems.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's your step-by-step skincare implementation:

**Week 1-2: Basics Only**
- Buy: Cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen
- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, moisturize
- Get consistent with this before adding anything

**Week 3-4: Assess and Adjust**
- Is skin tolerating basics well?
- Any reactions to products?
- Identify primary concern (acne, aging, etc.)

**Month 2: Add One Active**
- For acne: Start benzoyl peroxide OR tretinoin (not both)
- For aging: Start tretinoin OR vitamin C (pick one)
- Add slowly (2-3x/week first)

**Month 3-6: Build and Maintain**
- Increase frequency of actives as tolerated
- Full tretinoin use (nightly) if pursuing
- Evaluate progress monthly

**Ongoing: Consistency**
- Routine should take <5 min per session
- Results come from months/years of consistency
- Don't add new products constantly

**Product Recommendations:**
- Cleanser: CeraVe Foaming or Hydrating
- Moisturizer: CeraVe PM
- Sunscreen: EltaMD UV Clear
- Retinoid: Tretinoin 0.025% (prescription)

This is the evidence-based, no-BS approach. Simple, effective, sustainable.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta', 'tretinoin_guide'],
    },
  ],
};

The file /Users/imorgado/LOOKSMAXX/looksmaxx-app/src/data/guides/maintenance.ts has been updated. Here's the result of running `cat -n` on a snippet of the edited file:

toolUseResult.originalFile:
/**
 * General Maintenance Guide
 * Humor Level: High (25%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const maintenanceGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'maintenance',
  slug: 'general-maintenance',
  title: 'General Maintenance',
  subtitle: "The bare minimum that most guys still somehow miss",
  description: "Daily and weekly grooming habits that separate you from the NPCs. Non-negotiable baseline stuff.",
  icon: 'Wrench',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 10,
  order: 2,
  tags: ['grooming', 'hygiene', 'daily-routine', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['mindset', 'skincare'],
  productIds: [
    'tongue_scraper',
    'electric_toothbrush',
    'philips_oneblade',
    'nose_trimmer',
    'tweezers',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'cologne_bleu',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'hygiene-grooming',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'maintenance-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: '/guides/images/maintenance-hero.jpg',
    alt: 'Clean, well-groomed appearance',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The NPC Baseline',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Here's something that might hurt: most guys walking around have absolutely no idea how many basic maintenance things they're neglecting.

Nostril tentacles waving at people mid-conversation. Crusty lips. Unibrow situation developing. Breath that could clear a room.

**Nobody tells you this stuff.** Your friends won't. Your family's given up. Tinder matches just unmatch without explanation.

This guide is the checklist. The bare minimum. The "if you're not doing this, nothing else matters" baseline.

Everything here is simple. Nothing is expensive. No excuses.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'daily-oral',
      title: 'Daily: Oral Hygiene',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Your breath is out here committing war crimes and you don't even know it.

**The Protocol:**
1. **Brush 2x daily** — Electric toothbrush, 2 minutes minimum. If you're using a manual toothbrush in 2024, that's NPC behavior.
2. **Floss daily** — Yes, actually. The stuff between your teeth is rotting. Get string floss or a water flosser.
3. **Tongue scrape** — This is the secret weapon. 70% of bad breath comes from bacteria on your tongue. Takes 10 seconds, changes everything.

**The Reality Check:**
- You can't smell your own breath
- Everyone's too polite to tell you
- This is actively limiting your social and romantic life
- Fix it now`,
      products: ['tongue_scraper', 'electric_toothbrush'],
      tips: [
        'Scrape tongue BEFORE brushing, not after',
        'Replace toothbrush head every 3 months',
        'Mouthwash is optional but flossing is mandatory'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'tongue-scraping',
          type: 'gif',
          url: '/guides/gifs/tongue-scraping-technique.gif',
          alt: 'Proper tongue scraping technique',
          caption: 'Back to front, rinse scraper between strokes',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'daily-lips',
      title: 'Daily: Lip Care',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Crusty, chapped lips are sabotaging your entire face. The fix costs $5.

**Why This Matters:**
Your lips are one of the first things people notice. Dry, cracked lips read as "doesn't take care of himself" instantly.

**The Fix:**
- Apply lip balm or Aquaphor morning and night
- Reapply after eating or drinking
- At night, use a heavier occlusive (Aquaphor > chapstick)

**Common Mistakes:**
- Licking your lips (makes it worse)
- Flavored lip balms (you'll lick them)
- Forgetting entirely (check your lips right now)

**Pro tip:** Keep one by your bed, one in your pocket, one at your desk. The best lip balm is the one you actually use.`,
      products: ['aquaphor_lip'],
    },
    {
      id: 'weekly-nose-ear',
      title: 'Weekly: Nose & Ear Hair',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Nostril tentacles waving at people mid-conversation is an instant mog-killer. Nobody's going to tell you—they'll just slowly lose attraction and not know why.

**The Protocol:**
- Trim nose hairs weekly (Sunday maintenance)
- Check ear hair too (yes, you have some)
- Use a proper trimmer, not scissors (you WILL cut yourself)

**The Psychology:**
People rarely notice good grooming here, but they DEFINITELY notice when you neglect it. It's one of those things that can only hurt you, never help. Just eliminate it.

Get a trimmer. Use it weekly. This is bare minimum NPC maintenance, and you're not an NPC.`,
      products: ['nose_trimmer'],
      warnings: [
        "Don't use scissors inside your nose",
        "Don't pluck nose hairs (infection risk)"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'weekly-eyebrows',
      title: 'Weekly: Eyebrow Maintenance',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `There's a zone between "unibrow" and "Instagram influencer overplucked" that you're aiming for.

**What to Do:**
1. **Define the gap** — There should be clear separation between brows. Pluck strays between them.
2. **Clean the edges** — Remove random hairs above and below the brow line.
3. **Don't reshape** — You're cleaning, not redesigning. Keep your natural brow shape.

**What NOT to Do:**
- Don't thin them out (thicker brows = more masculine)
- Don't create an artificial arch
- Don't touch the main body of the brow
- Don't wax (too aggressive for maintenance)

**The Goal:**
Clean and intentional, not "did someone do your eyebrows?" If people can tell you've groomed them, you've gone too far.`,
      products: ['tweezers'],
      tips: [
        'Pluck after shower when pores are open',
        'Use natural light, bathroom lighting lies',
        'Take a step back every few hairs to check balance'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'weekly-facial-hair',
      title: 'Weekly: Facial Hair Management',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Whether you're going clean-shaven, stubble, or full beard—it needs to look intentional, not accidental.

**Clean-Shaven:**
- Shave every 1-3 days depending on growth
- Use a proper shave cream (not canned foam)
- Shave with the grain first, then against if needed
- Moisturize after

**Stubble:**
- This is the sweet spot for most faces
- Maintain at 1-3mm with a trimmer
- Clean up the neck and cheek lines
- Edge the mustache above the lip line

**Beard:**
- Keep it trimmed and shaped
- Define the neckline (2 fingers above Adam's apple)
- Use beard oil if longer than 1 week growth
- Wash it (yes, like hair)

**The Key:** Whatever style you choose, it should look like a choice, not like you ran out of razors.`,
      products: ['philips_oneblade', 'shaving_cream'],
    },
    {
      id: 'nails',
      title: 'Weekly: Nail Care',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Women notice nails immediately. Dirty, long, or bitten nails are an instant credibility killer.

**The Standard:**
- Trim weekly
- File rough edges (yes, men can use nail files)
- Clean under nails daily
- Push back cuticles after shower (optional but clean look)

**What You're Avoiding:**
- Nails that extend past fingertips
- Visible dirt under nails
- Ragged, bitten edges
- Hangnails

**No man has ever lost points for having clean, trimmed nails. Many have lost points for the opposite.**`,
      tips: [
        'Cut after shower when nails are softer',
        'Straight across, then round the corners slightly',
        "Keep a nail brush by the sink if you work with your hands"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fragrance',
      title: 'Daily: Scent Protocol',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Stop smelling like your high school gym locker. This ain't Axe bodyspray era anymore.

**The Layers:**
1. **Base** — Shower daily with unscented or lightly scented soap
2. **Deodorant** — Antiperspirant, applied at night (not morning)
3. **Fragrance** — 2-3 sprays MAX of a quality cologne

**Application:**
- Spray on pulse points: wrists, neck, chest
- Don't rub wrists together (breaks down scent)
- Less is more—you want a "lean in" scent, not an announcement

**Cologne Investment:**
One quality fragrance beats five cheap ones. Bleu de Chanel or similar safe bet. Get compliments, not complaints.

**The Test:** If people can smell you from more than arm's length, you've applied too much.`,
      products: ['cologne_bleu'],
      warnings: [
        'Never spray directly on clothes (stains and alters scent)',
        "Don't reapply throughout the day—your nose adapts, others can still smell it"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'hair',
      title: 'Daily: Hair Maintenance',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your hair is a major factor in your overall look. Neglecting it shows.

**Daily:**
- Style it. Every day. Even if it's a 2-minute routine.
- Use product appropriate to your hair type (matte for thin, pomade for thick)
- Don't touch it throughout the day (transfers oil)

**Every 4-6 Weeks:**
- Get it cut by a real barber
- Find a style that works for your face shape and hair type
- Bring reference photos (they're not just for women)

**Washing:**
- Most guys over-wash (strips natural oils)
- Every 2-3 days is usually enough
- Use conditioner if your hair is longer than 1 inch

**If Thinning:**
- Accept it early or treat it early
- Minoxidil + finasteride (consult a doctor)
- Or just buzz it—a clean shave beats a comb-over every time`,
      tips: [
        'Find one style and master it rather than switching constantly',
        'Take photos of good haircuts to show your barber',
        'Products for hold: wax > pomade > gel > mousse'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'checklist',
      title: 'The Weekly Checklist',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Print this. Put it on your bathroom mirror. No excuses.

**Daily:**
- [ ] Brush teeth (AM + PM)
- [ ] Floss
- [ ] Tongue scrape
- [ ] Apply lip balm
- [ ] Deodorant (night)
- [ ] Style hair
- [ ] Check mirror before leaving

**Weekly (Sunday Reset):**
- [ ] Trim nose/ear hair
- [ ] Eyebrow cleanup
- [ ] Facial hair maintenance
- [ ] Nail trim
- [ ] Deep clean ears

**Monthly:**
- [ ] Haircut
- [ ] Replace toothbrush head
- [ ] Inventory grooming supplies

**This is the baseline.** This is what separates "that guy takes care of himself" from "what's that smell?"

Lock in.`,
    },
  ],
};

toolUseResult.originalFile:
/**
 * Body Fat Mastery Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium-High (20%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const bodyFatGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'body-fat',
  slug: 'body-fat-mastery',
  title: 'Body Fat Mastery',
  subtitle: "Your jawline is in there somewhere—go find it",
  description: "The single biggest lever for facial aesthetics. Going from 18% to 12% body fat transforms your face.",
  icon: 'TrendingDown',
  humorLevel: 'medium-high',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 3,
  tags: ['body-fat', 'cutting', 'diet', 'facial-aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['diet', 'v-taper', 'training'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono'],
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Truth About Body Fat and Your Face',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `At 18% body fat, you're hoping good lighting saves you. At 11%, you ARE the good lighting.

Here's the brutal truth: you can have god-tier bone structure, but if it's buried under a layer of subcutaneous fat, you're frauding yourself out of your own genetics.

**Lean is life. Your jawline knows it.**

This isn't about being skinny. It's about being lean enough that your facial features actually show:
- Jawline definition
- Cheekbone projection
- Under-eye area (no fat pads)
- Neck/chin separation

Most guys have never seen their own bone structure because they've never been lean enough.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'bf-ranges',
      title: 'Body Fat Percentage Breakdown',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's be honest about what each range actually looks like:

| Body Fat % | What You See | Face Impact |
|------------|--------------|-------------|
| 20%+ | Soft everywhere, no definition | Buried jaw, soft cheeks, possible double chin |
| 17-20% | Some definition in good lighting | Jaw visible but soft, face holds water |
| 14-17% | Visible abs in good lighting | Decent definition, not optimal |
| 12-14% | Abs visible standing | Good facial definition, jaw pops |
| 10-12% | Clear 6-pack, veins showing | Excellent definition, cheekbones visible |
| 8-10% | Shredded, stage-ready | Maximum facial definition |
| <8% | Competition lean | Hard to maintain, not realistic long-term |

**The Sweet Spot: 10-14%**

This is where you're lean enough for facial definition but not so lean that you're constantly hungry, weak, and irritable. Most guys should aim for this range.

Below 10% is diminishing returns unless you're competing or doing a photoshoot.`,
      tips: [
        'Take photos in neutral lighting to assess—bathroom mirror lighting lies',
        'Measure waist circumference as a simple tracking metric',
        'DEXA scans are the gold standard for accuracy'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'where-fat-stores',
      title: 'Where Fat Stores (And Why Your Face Suffers)',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Fat distribution is genetic, but there's a general pattern:

**First to Store (Last to Lose):**
- Lower belly
- Love handles
- Lower back
- Face (buccal area, under chin)

**Last to Store (First to Lose):**
- Arms
- Upper chest
- Calves

**What This Means:**
Your face is often one of the LAST places to lean out. This is why guys at 18% think "I'm not even that fat" while their jaw is still buried.

**The Face Tax:**
If you carry fat in your face (many people do), you might need to get leaner than average to see facial definition. Someone might have a visible 6-pack at 14%, but their face doesn't pop until 11%.

It's not fair. It's genetics. Work with it.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'measuring',
      title: 'How to Actually Measure Body Fat',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most methods are garbage. Here's the hierarchy:

**Tier 1: DEXA Scan (Most Accurate)**
- $50-150 at clinics
- Tells you exactly where fat is distributed
- Worth getting once to establish baseline

**Tier 2: Calipers (Decent If Done Right)**
- $15 for calipers
- 7-site measurement protocol
- Requires practice and consistency
- ±3% error margin

**Tier 3: Navy Method (Free, Okay)**
- Uses neck and waist measurements
- Formula-based estimate
- Better than nothing

**Tier 4: Bioelectrical Impedance (Mostly Useless)**
- Those scales and gym machines
- Varies wildly based on hydration
- Can be off by 5-10%
- Only useful for tracking trends, not absolute numbers

**Tier 5: Mirror + Photos (Subjective But Real)**
- Compare to reference photos at known body fat %
- Track progress over time
- Lighting consistent, same time of day

**Recommendation:** Get a DEXA scan once, then track via photos and waist measurement.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-math',
      title: 'The Fat Loss Equation',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `This is simple math. Not easy, but simple.

**The Formula:**
Calories In < Calories Out = Fat Loss

That's it. There's no metabolic magic. No foods that "burn fat." No supplements that override physics.

**Setting Your Deficit:**
1. Calculate maintenance calories (TDEE)
2. Subtract 300-500 calories
3. Adjust based on results

**Rate of Loss:**
- 0.5-1% of bodyweight per week is sustainable
- Faster = muscle loss, metabolic adaptation, rebound
- Slower = patience required but better preservation

**For a 180lb guy:**
- 0.9-1.8 lbs per week is the target
- That's a 450-900 calorie daily deficit
- 10 lbs of fat takes 5-10 weeks minimum

**The Reality:** Most guys try to cut too fast, lose muscle, feel like death, and rebound. Don't be that guy.`,
      tips: [
        '500 calorie deficit = ~1 lb fat loss per week',
        'Weigh daily, average weekly (weight fluctuates)',
        "If you're not losing, you're eating more than you think"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein-priority',
      title: 'Protein: The Non-Negotiable',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `When cutting, protein is king. Everything else is secondary.

**Why Protein Matters:**
- Preserves muscle mass during deficit
- Most satiating macronutrient (keeps you full)
- Highest thermic effect (burns calories to digest)
- Prevents the "skinny fat" look

**How Much:**
- 0.8-1g per pound of bodyweight
- 180lb guy = 144-180g protein daily
- Yes, this seems like a lot. Yes, it's necessary.

**How to Hit It:**
- Prioritize protein at every meal
- Track for a few weeks until you know your foods
- Protein sources: meat, fish, eggs, dairy, protein powder

**Example Day (180g protein):**
- Breakfast: 4 eggs + greek yogurt = 40g
- Lunch: 8oz chicken breast + cottage cheese = 60g
- Dinner: 8oz salmon + protein shake = 60g
- Snack: Protein bar = 20g

If you're consistently under on protein, you're going to lose muscle and end up looking worse at the same weight.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
    {
      id: 'water-and-bloat',
      title: 'Water Weight and Facial Bloat',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're not drinking enough water. Yes, you. Your face is literally retaining fluid to compensate.

**The Paradox:**
Drink MORE water to hold LESS water. Your body retains fluid when dehydrated.

**The Protocol:**
- Minimum 0.5 oz per lb of bodyweight
- 180lb guy = 90oz minimum (about 3 liters)
- More if training or sweating

**What Causes Facial Bloat:**
1. **Sodium** — High salt = water retention
2. **Alcohol** — Dehydrates, then overcompensates
3. **Carbs** — Each gram stores 3-4g of water
4. **Sleep deprivation** — Cortisol = water retention
5. **Dehydration** — Counter-intuitive but true

**The Morning Difference:**
Ever notice you look leaner in the morning? You're slightly dehydrated after 8 hours without water. This is why fighters cut water weight—it makes a visible difference.

For consistent leanness, stay consistently hydrated and keep sodium moderate (not zero, just not excessive).`,
      products: ['water_jug'],
      tips: [
        'Drink a full glass of water immediately upon waking',
        'Cut sodium 24-48 hours before photos for temporary tightness',
        "Alcohol is the worst for next-day face bloat"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'timeline',
      title: 'Realistic Cutting Timeline',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's set realistic expectations:

**Starting Point: 20% Body Fat (180lb guy)**
- Goal: 12% body fat
- Fat to lose: ~15 lbs
- Timeline: 10-15 weeks (doing it right)

**Week by Week:**
- Week 1-2: Water weight drops, scale moves fast
- Week 3-6: Steady loss, starting to see changes
- Week 7-10: Face starts tightening, jaw appearing
- Week 11-15: Final stubborn fat, face pops

**The Trap:**
Weeks 6-10 are where most guys quit. Scale slows, you don't see daily changes, and pizza sounds really good.

**The Reality:**
Fat loss in the face often happens in the final phase. You might look the same for weeks, then suddenly "damn, there's my jawline."

Be patient. Trust the deficit. Don't quit in the middle of the transformation.`,
      warnings: [
        "Don't cut harder because the scale slowed—you'll lose muscle",
        'Take weekly photos in the same conditions for accurate comparison'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'maintaining',
      title: 'Maintaining Lean (The Hard Part)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Getting lean is one thing. Staying lean is another.

**Why Maintenance Is Hard:**
- Hunger hormones increase after cutting
- Metabolism adapts (slightly) to lower calories
- One vacation can undo weeks of progress
- Life happens

**The Strategy:**
1. **Reverse diet** — Slowly increase calories after cutting
2. **Stay active** — NEAT (daily movement) matters as much as gym
3. **Keep tracking** — At least loosely, forever
4. **Set a ceiling** — "I never go above 15%" as a rule

**The Buffer Zone:**
Cutting to 11% then maintaining at 13% is easier than trying to stay at 11% year-round. Give yourself a 2-3% buffer for life fluctuations.

**The Long Game:**
Most guys yo-yo because they treat cutting as temporary. Make leanness part of your identity, not a phase.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'common-mistakes',
      title: 'Common Cutting Mistakes',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Don't be this guy:

**Mistake 1: Cutting Too Fast**
"I'll just eat 1200 calories and do 2 hours of cardio."
Result: Lose muscle, crash metabolism, binge, end up fatter than before.

**Mistake 2: Ignoring Protein**
"I'm just not going to eat much."
Result: Skinny-fat physique, lost the muscle, kept the face fat.

**Mistake 3: Weekend Cheats**
"I was good all week!"
Result: 3500 calorie surplus Saturday-Sunday wipes out the weekly deficit.

**Mistake 4: Drinking Calories**
"But it's just juice/beer/coffee drinks."
Result: 500+ invisible calories daily, no satiety, confused why scale won't move.

**Mistake 5: No Resistance Training**
"I just need to do cardio to lose weight."
Result: Lost 20 lbs—15 of muscle. Now you're a smaller, softer version of yourself.

**Mistake 6: Obsessing Over the Scale**
"I gained 2 lbs overnight, I'm done!"
Result: Water fluctuation caused a mental breakdown. Real progress lost in the noise.

Avoid these and you're ahead of 90% of people trying to cut.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's exactly what to do:

**Step 1: Establish Baseline**
- Get a DEXA scan or estimate body fat from photos
- Calculate TDEE (plenty of calculators online)
- Take photos in consistent lighting

**Step 2: Set Up Tracking**
- Download a calorie tracking app
- Get a food scale (non-negotiable for accuracy)
- Set protein and calorie targets

**Step 3: Start the Cut**
- 300-500 calorie deficit
- Hit protein daily (0.8-1g/lb)
- Lift weights 3-4x per week (don't just do cardio)

**Step 4: Monitor and Adjust**
- Weigh daily, average weekly
- If not losing after 2 weeks, reduce by 100-200 calories
- Take weekly photos in same conditions

**Step 5: Be Patient**
- Expect 10-15 weeks for a significant cut
- Facial changes come last—don't quit early
- Adjust timeline based on actual progress

**Your face will thank you. Lock in.**`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
  ],
};

/**
 * Training Splits Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const trainingGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'training',
  slug: 'training-splits',
  title: 'Training Splits',
  subtitle: "Stop wandering the gym confused",
  description: "Structured workout programs for different experience levels and schedules. No more random workouts.",
  icon: 'Calendar',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 5,
  tags: ['training', 'workout', 'gym', 'programming', 'splits'],
  relatedGuides: ['v-taper', 'core-neck', 'cardio'],
  productIds: ['creatine_mono'],
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'Why Your Split Matters',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Walking into the gym without a plan is like going to the grocery store hungry—you'll make bad decisions and leave unsatisfied.

**The Problem:**
Most guys either:
- Do random exercises they saw on Instagram
- Hit chest and arms every day, ignoring everything else
- Overcomplicate with 6-day PPL splits when they can barely make it 3x/week
- Follow a pro bodybuilder's routine when they've been lifting for 6 months

**The Fix:**
Choose a split that matches your:
- Available training days
- Experience level
- Recovery capacity
- Goals

Then stick with it for at least 8-12 weeks before changing anything.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'fundamentals',
      title: 'Training Fundamentals (All Splits)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Before we get into splits, these principles apply to everything:

**1. Progressive Overload**
You must increase weight, reps, or sets over time. If you're lifting the same weight for the same reps month after month, you're not growing.

**2. Volume Matters**
10-20 sets per muscle group per week is the hypertrophy sweet spot. Less than 10 is probably not enough. More than 20 has diminishing returns.

**3. Intensity (Effort)**
Most sets should be within 1-3 reps of failure. If you could do 5 more reps, you're not working hard enough.

**4. Recovery**
Muscles grow when you rest, not when you lift. Sleep 7-9 hours. Eat enough protein. Take rest days seriously.

**5. Consistency > Perfection**
A 3-day routine done consistently beats a 6-day routine you keep missing. Pick something sustainable.`,
      tips: [
        'Track your lifts—what gets measured gets managed',
        'Deload every 4-6 weeks (reduce volume or intensity)',
        'Sleep is anabolic. 6 hours is not enough.'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'full-body',
      title: 'Full Body Split (3 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Beginners (first 6-12 months)
- Busy schedules (only 3 gym days)
- Coming back after time off

**Why It Works:**
- High frequency per muscle (3x/week)
- More practice with compounds
- Easy to schedule
- Excellent for building foundation

**Sample Week:**

**Day 1 (Mon):**
- Squat: 3x8-10
- Bench Press: 3x8-10
- Barbell Row: 3x8-10
- Overhead Press: 3x10-12
- Bicep Curls: 2x12-15

**Day 2 (Wed):**
- Deadlift: 3x5
- Incline DB Press: 3x10-12
- Lat Pulldown: 3x10-12
- Leg Press: 3x12-15
- Tricep Pushdowns: 2x12-15

**Day 3 (Fri):**
- Squat: 3x8-10
- Overhead Press: 3x8-10
- Pull-Ups: 3xMax
- Romanian Deadlift: 3x10-12
- Face Pulls: 3x15-20

**Progression:**
Add 5 lbs to lower body lifts and 2.5 lbs to upper body lifts each session when you complete all reps.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'upper-lower',
      title: 'Upper/Lower Split (4 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Intermediate lifters (1+ years)
- Those with 4 consistent gym days
- Balanced development focus

**Why It Works:**
- Good frequency (2x per muscle per week)
- Better recovery than PPL
- More volume per session than full body
- Flexible scheduling (can rest between any day)

**Sample Week:**

**Upper A (Mon):**
- Bench Press: 4x6-8
- Barbell Row: 4x6-8
- Overhead Press: 3x8-10
- Pull-Ups: 3x8-12
- Lateral Raises: 3x15-20
- Tricep Work: 3x10-12

**Lower A (Tue):**
- Squat: 4x6-8
- Romanian Deadlift: 3x8-10
- Leg Press: 3x10-12
- Leg Curl: 3x10-12
- Calf Raises: 4x15-20

**Upper B (Thu):**
- Overhead Press: 4x6-8
- Weighted Pull-Ups: 4x6-8
- Incline DB Press: 3x10-12
- Cable Rows: 3x10-12
- Face Pulls: 3x15-20
- Bicep Curls: 3x10-12

**Lower B (Fri):**
- Deadlift: 3x5
- Front Squat: 3x8-10
- Walking Lunges: 3x10/leg
- Leg Curl: 3x10-12
- Calf Raises: 4x15-20

**Notes:**
- Day A = heavier, Day B = moderate weight, more reps
- Rest at least one day between training the same muscles`,
    },
    {
      id: 'ppl',
      title: 'Push/Pull/Legs Split (6 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Intermediate to advanced (2+ years)
- Those with 5-6 gym days available
- Maximum volume and frequency goals

**Why It Works:**
- High frequency (2x per muscle per week)
- High volume per session
- Clear organization
- Most popular split for bodybuilding

**Sample Week:**

**Push A (Mon):**
- Bench Press: 4x6-8
- Overhead Press: 3x8-10
- Incline DB Press: 3x10-12
- Lateral Raises: 4x15-20
- Tricep Dips: 3x8-12
- Cable Tricep Pushdowns: 3x12-15

**Pull A (Tue):**
- Deadlift: 3x5
- Pull-Ups: 4x8-12
- Barbell Rows: 3x8-10
- Face Pulls: 4x15-20
- Barbell Curls: 3x10-12
- Hammer Curls: 3x12-15

**Legs A (Wed):**
- Squat: 4x6-8
- Romanian Deadlift: 3x10-12
- Leg Press: 3x12-15
- Leg Curl: 3x10-12
- Calf Raises: 4x15-20

**Push B (Thu):**
- Overhead Press: 4x6-8
- Incline Bench: 3x8-10
- Cable Flies: 3x12-15
- Lateral Raises: 4x15-20
- Skull Crushers: 3x10-12
- Overhead Tricep Extension: 3x12-15

**Pull B (Fri):**
- Barbell Row: 4x6-8
- Lat Pulldown: 3x10-12
- Seated Cable Row: 3x10-12
- Rear Delt Flies: 4x15-20
- Incline DB Curls: 3x10-12
- Cable Curls: 3x12-15

**Legs B (Sat):**
- Front Squat: 4x8-10
- Walking Lunges: 3x12/leg
- Leg Extension: 3x12-15
- Leg Curl: 3x10-12
- Seated Calf Raises: 4x15-20

**Warning:**
This is a lot of volume. If you're not sleeping 8+ hours and eating 1g/lb protein, you won't recover properly.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'bro-split',
      title: 'Bro Split (5 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `**The Classic:**
- Monday: Chest
- Tuesday: Back
- Wednesday: Shoulders
- Thursday: Arms
- Friday: Legs

**The Truth:**
The bro split is often mocked as "suboptimal" because each muscle only gets hit once per week. Science says 2x per week frequency is better for hypertrophy.

**But Here's the Thing:**
If you've been training for years and want maximum volume per session, or if it's the only split you'll stick to consistently, it can still work.

**When It Makes Sense:**
- Advanced lifters who need 15-20+ sets per muscle
- Those who enjoy destroying one muscle group per session
- People who've tried other splits and prefer this

**When It Doesn't:**
- Beginners (you don't need that much volume)
- People who miss gym days frequently (then you never hit that muscle)
- Natural lifters who benefit from frequency

**The Compromise:**
If you like the bro split style, consider hitting each muscle 1.5x per week:
- Chest + Triceps
- Back + Biceps
- Shoulders + Legs (light)
- Arms + Rear Delts
- Legs (heavy)`,
    },
    {
      id: 'exercise-selection',
      title: 'Choosing the Right Exercises',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Not all exercises are equal. Here's how to prioritize:

**Tier 1: Compound Movements (Build Your Foundation)**
These should make up 60-70% of your training:
- Squat variations
- Deadlift variations
- Bench press variations
- Overhead press variations
- Row variations
- Pull-up/pulldown variations

**Tier 2: Compound Accessories (Support Development)**
- Lunges, leg press, RDLs
- Dips, incline press
- Face pulls, rear delt work
- Curl and tricep compound movements

**Tier 3: Isolation (Target Weaknesses)**
- Lateral raises (for V-taper)
- Bicep curls (for arm peak)
- Tricep extensions (for arm size)
- Leg curls/extensions (for leg detail)
- Calf raises (for calf size)

**The Mistake:**
Building your routine around cable machines and isolation exercises. These are supplements to compounds, not replacements.`,
      tips: [
        'Master form on compounds before going heavy',
        'Isolations are for lagging body parts',
        'If short on time, cut isolations first, never compounds'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'rep-ranges',
      title: 'Rep Ranges and What They Do',
      humorLevel: 'low',
      content: `Different rep ranges serve different purposes:

**1-5 Reps (Strength Focus)**
- Heavy weight, low reps
- Best for building maximal strength
- Less time under tension for hypertrophy
- Good for compounds (squat, bench, deadlift)

**6-12 Reps (Hypertrophy Sweet Spot)**
- Moderate weight, moderate reps
- Best for muscle growth
- Good balance of mechanical tension and metabolic stress
- Where most of your training should live

**12-20+ Reps (Metabolic/Endurance)**
- Lighter weight, high reps
- Great for smaller muscles (side delts, rear delts)
- Good for pump and finishing sets
- Less effective for large muscle growth

**The Reality:**
Muscles grow across all rep ranges when taken close to failure. The "6-12 for hypertrophy" rule is a guideline, not a law.

**Practical Application:**
- Compounds: 5-10 reps
- Secondary compounds: 8-12 reps
- Isolations: 10-20 reps

Mix it up within these guidelines for variety.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'progression',
      title: 'How to Progress',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you're not progressing, you're not growing. Here's how to ensure constant improvement:

**Method 1: Linear Progression (Beginners)**
Add weight every session:
- Week 1: Bench 135 x 3x8
- Week 2: Bench 140 x 3x8
- Week 3: Bench 145 x 3x8
- Continue until you stall

**Method 2: Double Progression (Intermediate)**
Work within a rep range, increase weight when you hit the top:
- Week 1: 185 x 3x8
- Week 2: 185 x 3x9
- Week 3: 185 x 3x10
- Week 4: 190 x 3x8 (restart)

**Method 3: Volume Progression (Advanced)**
Keep weight same, add sets:
- Week 1: 3 sets
- Week 2: 4 sets
- Week 3: 5 sets
- Week 4: Deload

**When You Stall:**
1. Check sleep and nutrition first
2. Deload (reduce volume/intensity for 1 week)
3. Try a different rep range or exercise variation
4. Accept that progress slows after the beginner phase`,
    },
    {
      id: 'choosing-split',
      title: 'Which Split Should You Choose?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The best split is the one you'll actually do consistently. Here's the decision tree:

**How many days can you REALISTICALLY train per week?**

**3 Days → Full Body**
- Best bang for buck with limited time
- Perfect for beginners

**4 Days → Upper/Lower**
- Great balance of volume and recovery
- Good for most intermediates

**5 Days → Upper/Lower/Upper/Lower/Full or PPL**
- More flexibility
- Good volume and frequency

**6 Days → PPL (Push/Pull/Legs 2x)**
- Maximum volume and frequency
- Requires excellent recovery
- Advanced or those with great genetics

**Be Honest With Yourself:**
If you're planning a 6-day split but realistically make it to the gym 3-4 times per week, you're doing yourself a disservice. A 4-day split done consistently beats a 6-day split done randomly.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what to do:

**Step 1: Choose Your Split**
Based on your available training days and experience level. When in doubt, go with fewer days and build up.

**Step 2: Write It Down**
Physically write or type your routine. Every exercise, sets, reps, and rest periods.

**Step 3: Track Every Workout**
Use an app or notebook. Record weight x reps for every set.

**Step 4: Progress Each Session**
Add weight, reps, or sets whenever possible. If you completed all prescribed reps, increase something next time.

**Step 5: Stick With It**
Minimum 8-12 weeks before changing programs. Program hopping is one of the biggest gains killers.

**Step 6: Deload When Needed**
Every 4-6 weeks, take a lighter week. This isn't weakness—it's smart programming.

The gym is simple: show up, lift more than last time, recover, repeat. Don't overcomplicate it.`,
    },
  ],
};

/**
 * Diet & Nutrition Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const dietGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'diet',
  slug: 'diet-nutrition',
  title: 'Diet & Nutrition',
  subtitle: "You can't out-train a bad diet",
  description: "The fundamentals of eating for aesthetics. Protein, calories, and what actually matters vs what doesn't.",
  icon: 'Utensils',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 15,
  order: 8,
  tags: ['nutrition', 'diet', 'protein', 'calories', 'macros'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'v-taper'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'collagen_peptides', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate'],
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Foundation of Everything',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your physique is built in the kitchen, revealed in the gym.

You can train perfectly, but if your nutrition is garbage:
- You won't build muscle efficiently
- You won't lose fat predictably
- You'll look the same in 6 months

**The Good News:**
Nutrition is simpler than the internet makes it seem. Most of the complexity is unnecessary.

**What Actually Matters (80% of results):**
1. Total calories (energy balance)
2. Protein intake
3. Food quality (mostly)
4. Consistency

**What Barely Matters (20% optimization):**
- Meal timing
- Specific food choices within reason
- Supplement stacks beyond basics
- Nutrient timing around workouts

Let's cover the 80% first.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'calories',
      title: 'Calories: The Master Variable',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Everything else is secondary to energy balance.

**The Basic Math:**
- Calories In > Calories Out = Weight Gain
- Calories In < Calories Out = Weight Loss
- Calories In = Calories Out = Maintenance

**Finding Your Maintenance:**
Method 1: Calculator estimate
- TDEE calculator gives starting point
- Typically 14-17 x bodyweight (in lbs)
- Active people higher, sedentary lower

Method 2: Track and observe
- Eat the same for 2 weeks
- Track weight daily, average weekly
- Stable = maintenance. Rising = surplus. Dropping = deficit.

**Setting Your Target:**

| Goal | Calorie Target |
|------|---------------|
| Fat Loss | Maintenance - 300-500 |
| Maintenance | TDEE |
| Lean Bulk | Maintenance + 200-300 |
| Standard Bulk | Maintenance + 400-500 |

**The Mistake:**
Going too aggressive. A 1000 calorie deficit sounds fast but leads to muscle loss, metabolic adaptation, and binges. Slow and steady wins.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
      tips: [
        'Use a food scale for accuracy—eyeballing is notoriously wrong',
        'Track for 2-4 weeks to learn your foods, then you can estimate',
        'Weekly average matters more than daily fluctuations'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein',
      title: 'Protein: The King of Macros',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you remember one thing from this guide: hit your protein.

**Why Protein Is King:**
- Builds and preserves muscle
- Most satiating macro (keeps you full)
- Highest thermic effect (burns calories to digest)
- Hardest to store as fat

**How Much:**
- Minimum: 0.7g per pound of bodyweight
- Optimal: 0.8-1g per pound of bodyweight
- Upper limit: More than 1.2g/lb has no additional benefit

**For a 180lb Guy:**
- Minimum: 126g daily
- Optimal: 144-180g daily

**Best Protein Sources:**

| Source | Protein per 100g |
|--------|-----------------|
| Chicken breast | 31g |
| Lean beef | 26g |
| Salmon | 25g |
| Greek yogurt | 10g |
| Eggs | 13g |
| Cottage cheese | 11g |
| Whey protein | 80g |

**Hitting It Daily:**
- Each meal should have a protein source
- 30-50g per meal, 3-4 meals
- Fill gaps with protein shakes if needed
- Front-load protein earlier in day for satiety`,
    },
    {
      id: 'carbs-fats',
      title: 'Carbs and Fats: The Flexible Macros',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `After calories and protein, carbs and fats are flexible. Here's how to think about them:

**Fats: The Minimum**
- Never go below 0.3g/lb bodyweight
- Fats are essential for hormones (testosterone)
- Too low = hormone problems, brain fog, bad skin
- For 180lb: minimum 54g fat daily

**Carbs: The Performance Fuel**
- Not "essential" but highly beneficial for training
- Fill remaining calories after protein and fat
- More carbs = better gym performance
- Lower carbs = some people do better for fat loss

**Setting Macros (Example: 180lb guy, 2500 calories)**

Option 1: Moderate carb (recommended)
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 80g (720 cal)
- Carbs: 265g (1060 cal)

Option 2: Lower carb
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 100g (900 cal)
- Carbs: 220g (880 cal)

Option 3: Higher carb (athletic)
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 60g (540 cal)
- Carbs: 310g (1240 cal)

**The Truth:**
For most people, the exact ratio doesn't matter much. Hit protein, stay in your calorie range, and adjust carbs/fats based on preference and how you feel.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'food-quality',
      title: 'Food Quality: What to Actually Eat',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Here's where things get simpler than the internet suggests:

**The 80/20 Rule:**
- 80% whole, minimally processed foods
- 20% whatever you want

This keeps you sane while getting results.

**Whole Foods (Prioritize These):**

**Proteins:**
- Chicken, turkey, lean beef, fish
- Eggs, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese
- Whey/casein protein powder

**Carbs:**
- Rice, potatoes, oats
- Fruits, vegetables
- Whole grain bread/pasta

**Fats:**
- Olive oil, avocados
- Nuts, seeds
- Fatty fish (salmon)
- Eggs

**Minimize (Not Eliminate):**
- Fried foods
- Sugary snacks and drinks
- Processed meats regularly
- Alcohol (empty calories + lowers testosterone + disrupts sleep)

**The Why:**
Whole foods are more filling per calorie, have more micronutrients, and are harder to overeat. You can lose weight on junk food (calories are calories), but you'll be hungrier and less healthy.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'meal-structure',
      title: 'Meal Structure and Timing',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Meal timing is overrated for results but matters for adherence and performance.

**The Basics:**
- Total daily intake matters more than timing
- 3-5 meals per day works for most people
- Don't overthink it

**What Slightly Matters:**

1. **Pre-Workout (1-2 hours before)**
   - Carbs + protein = better performance
   - Don't train completely fasted if you can help it
   - Something > nothing

2. **Post-Workout (within 2-3 hours)**
   - Protein helps start recovery
   - The "anabolic window" is way longer than old bro-science claimed
   - Just eat normally, don't stress

3. **Before Bed**
   - Casein or slow protein can help overnight recovery
   - Not essential, just nice

**A Simple Day Structure:**

- Breakfast: Protein + carbs + fats
- Lunch: Protein + carbs + vegetables
- Pre-workout: Light carbs + protein if needed
- Dinner: Protein + carbs + vegetables
- Optional snack: Protein if needed to hit target

**Intermittent Fasting:**
Some people like it. It doesn't burn more fat, but it can help control calories if you're bad at small meals. Personal preference.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'cutting',
      title: 'Eating for Fat Loss',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `When cutting, everything matters a bit more:

**The Setup:**
1. Calculate maintenance calories
2. Subtract 300-500 calories
3. Set protein at 1g/lb (higher end when cutting)
4. Fill remaining with carbs and fats

**Maximizing Satiety:**
- High volume, low calorie foods (vegetables, lean proteins)
- More protein = more fullness
- High fiber foods
- Drink water before meals
- Eat slowly

**Volume Eating Foods:**
| Food | Calories per 100g |
|------|------------------|
| Lettuce | 5 |
| Cucumber | 16 |
| Egg whites | 52 |
| Chicken breast | 165 |
| Potatoes (boiled) | 77 |
| Greek yogurt (0%) | 59 |

You can eat 500g of potatoes for the same calories as 50g of chips. Volume matters.

**Cutting Mistakes:**
1. Going too aggressive (muscle loss, rebound)
2. Cutting protein (preserves muscle)
3. Eliminating carbs entirely (tanks performance)
4. Weekend binges (erases weekly deficit)
5. Not tracking (guessing incorrectly)`,
      tips: [
        'Weigh daily, average weekly—weight fluctuates',
        "0.5-1% of bodyweight loss per week is optimal",
        'Hunger is normal but not unbearable—adjust if miserable'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'bulking',
      title: 'Eating for Muscle Gain',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Bulking done right builds muscle. Bulking done wrong just makes you fat.

**The Setup:**
1. Calculate maintenance
2. Add 200-300 calories (lean bulk) or 400-500 (standard bulk)
3. Set protein at 0.8-1g/lb
4. Distribute remaining to carbs and fats (favor carbs for training)

**Lean Bulk vs Dirty Bulk:**

| Approach | Surplus | Result |
|----------|---------|--------|
| Lean bulk | +200-300 | Slow muscle gain, minimal fat |
| Standard bulk | +400-500 | Good muscle gain, some fat |
| Dirty bulk | +1000+ | Some muscle, lots of fat |

**Recommendation:**
Lean bulk unless you're very underweight. Gaining fat doesn't build muscle faster, it just means a longer cut later.

**Weight Gain Rate:**
- Beginners: 2-4 lbs/month possible
- Intermediate: 1-2 lbs/month realistic
- Advanced: 0.5-1 lb/month if lucky

**If weight isn't going up:**
You're not eating enough. Track more accurately and add 100-200 calories.

**Bulking Mistakes:**
1. Gaining too fast ("I'll cut later" → never cuts)
2. Dirty bulking (just makes you fat)
3. Not tracking (surplus might actually be deficit)
4. Using bulk as excuse to eat garbage`,
    },
    {
      id: 'supplements',
      title: 'Supplements That Actually Work',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Most supplements are garbage. Here's what's worth your money:

**Tier 1: Actually Works**

1. **Creatine Monohydrate**
   - 5g daily, any time
   - Strength, size, cognition
   - Costs $0.10/day
   - No loading needed

2. **Protein Powder**
   - Convenient protein source
   - Whey, casein, or plant-based
   - Not magic, just food in powder form

3. **Vitamin D3**
   - Most people are deficient
   - 2000-5000 IU daily
   - Get blood work to confirm

4. **Omega-3 (Fish Oil)**
   - Anti-inflammatory
   - Brain and heart health
   - 2-3g EPA/DHA daily

**Tier 2: Situationally Useful**

5. **Caffeine** — Performance boost (from coffee is fine)
6. **Magnesium** — Most people are deficient, helps sleep
7. **Collagen** — May help joints and skin
8. **Zinc** — If deficient (many are)

**Tier 3: Probably Wasting Money**

- BCAAs (get protein instead)
- Fat burners (mostly caffeine + fillers)
- Testosterone boosters (don't work)
- Most pre-workouts (caffeine + expensive pixie dust)

**The Rule:**
Get 95% of results from food. Use supplements to fill gaps, not replace meals.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate', 'collagen_peptides'],
    },
    {
      id: 'practical',
      title: 'Practical Meal Prep',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Knowing what to eat is useless if you don't actually do it. Here's how:

**The Basics of Meal Prep:**
1. Pick 2-3 protein sources
2. Pick 2-3 carb sources
3. Pick vegetables
4. Cook in bulk
5. Store in containers
6. Eat throughout week

**Simple Prep (Sunday, 2 hours):**

**Proteins:**
- 2 lbs chicken breast (baked or grilled)
- 1 lb ground turkey or lean beef
- 1 dozen hard boiled eggs

**Carbs:**
- Big batch of rice (rice cooker)
- Bag of potatoes (roasted or boiled)
- Oats (just need measuring)

**Vegetables:**
- Pre-washed salad bags
- Broccoli/green beans (steam or roast)
- Frozen vegetables (microwave)

**Assembly:**
Each meal: 6-8oz protein + 1 cup carbs + vegetables

**If You Hate Meal Prep:**
- Buy pre-cooked rotisserie chicken
- Microwave rice packets
- Pre-cut vegetables
- More expensive but still works

**Eating Out:**
- Prioritize protein (grilled chicken, fish, steak)
- Ask for dressing on side
- Skip the bread basket
- Don't drink calories
- It's not that complicated`,
    },
    {
      id: 'common-mistakes',
      title: 'Common Nutrition Mistakes',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Don't be this guy:

**Mistake 1: Not Tracking**
"I eat healthy but can't lose weight."
You're eating more than you think. Track for 2 weeks. I promise.

**Mistake 2: Drinking Calories**
Soda, juice, alcohol, fancy coffee drinks. 500+ invisible calories daily. Switch to water, black coffee, diet drinks.

**Mistake 3: Weekend Destruction**
5 days of deficit, 2 days of surplus = maintenance. The weekend counts.

**Mistake 4: All-or-Nothing**
One bad meal doesn't ruin the week. Just get back on track. Don't spiral into "I already messed up so..."

**Mistake 5: Avoiding Carbs**
Carbs aren't the enemy. Excess calories are. Low carb works by reducing calories, not magic.

**Mistake 6: Not Eating Enough Protein**
"I think I get enough." You probably don't. Track it. 0.8-1g/lb is more than most people think.

**Mistake 7: Relying on Supplements**
No supplement will fix a bad diet. Food first, supplements for gaps.

**Mistake 8: Overcomplicating**
Meal timing, food combining, "clean eating" obsession. Hit calories and protein. That's 80% of it.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's exactly what to do:

**Week 1: Baseline**
- Download a tracking app (MyFitnessPal, Cronometer)
- Get a food scale
- Track everything you eat for 7 days (no changes)
- See where you actually are

**Week 2: Adjust**
- Calculate your calorie target based on goal
- Set protein target (0.8-1g/lb)
- Start hitting these targets

**Week 3-4: Dial In**
- Monitor weight trends
- Adjust calories if needed (not losing? Reduce by 100-200)
- Find meals that work for you
- Build a rotation of go-to meals

**Ongoing: Optimize**
- Track until you can estimate accurately
- Meal prep to stay consistent
- Weigh weekly, adjust as needed
- Don't overcomplicate

**The Truth:**
Most of your results come from:
1. Eating in the right calorie range
2. Hitting protein consistently
3. Doing this for months/years

Everything else is optimization. Master these three first.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
  ],
};

/**
 * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide
 * Humor Level: High (30%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'mindset',
  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
  icon: 'Brain',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 1,
  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: [],
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Real Talk',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.

But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**

They're either:
- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)

This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-1-perfectionism',
      title: 'Mistake #1: Waiting for the "Perfect" Plan',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You've bookmarked 47 articles. You've saved 200 Instagram posts. You've downloaded 12 PDFs. You've done exactly **zero** actual work.

**This ain't it, chief.**

The perfect routine doesn't exist. There's no secret combination of products and exercises that will unlock chad-tier genetics. There's just consistent effort over time.

Here's the brutal truth: a mediocre plan executed consistently beats a perfect plan you never start.

**Action Step:** Pick ONE thing from this app to improve. Just one. Do it for 30 days before adding anything else.`,
      tips: [
        'Done is better than perfect',
        'Consistency beats intensity every single time',
        'Start before you feel ready'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-2-timeline',
      title: 'Mistake #2: Expecting Fast Results',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `You started mewing yesterday and you're checking your jawline in the mirror this morning. Bro.

Real change takes **months to years**, depending on what you're working on:

| Change | Timeline |
|--------|----------|
| Better skin (routine) | 6-12 weeks |
| Body recomposition | 3-6 months |
| Posture improvement | 3-6 months |
| Hair regrowth (minox) | 6-12 months |
| Mewing (adults) | 1-2+ years |

**The guys who win are the ones who forget about results and just lock in on the process.**

Think about it: if you had started 6 months ago, you'd already be there. You didn't. So start now and stop checking daily.`,
      warnings: [
        'Taking progress photos daily will drive you insane',
        'Monthly or bi-monthly comparison photos are enough'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-3-comparison',
      title: 'Mistake #3: Comparing to Genetic Outliers',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're comparing yourself to guys who:
- Won the genetic lottery
- Have professional lighting in every photo
- Are on gear and won't admit it
- Use filters/editing
- Got surgery and claim "just mewing bro"

**This is NPC behavior.**

Here's a better frame: you're not trying to become someone else. You're trying to mog your past self. That's it.

Your only competition is the guy you were 6 months ago. If he'd be jealous of where you are now, you're winning.`,
      tips: [
        'Mog your past self, not strangers on the internet',
        'Unfollow accounts that make you feel like garbage',
        'Follow for information, not comparison'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-4-shortcuts',
      title: 'Mistake #4: Looking for Shortcuts',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."

The internet is full of people trying to sell you things you don't need:
- Miracle supplements that do nothing
- Expensive gadgets that collect dust
- "Secret" techniques that are just repackaged basics

**Here's what actually works:**
1. Sleep 7-9 hours
2. Eat enough protein
3. Lift weights
4. Use sunscreen
5. Stay lean
6. Groom yourself

That's 90% of it. Everything else is optimization on top of this foundation. If you're not doing these six things consistently, nothing else matters.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-5-all-or-nothing',
      title: 'Mistake #5: All-or-Nothing Thinking',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."
You eat one bad meal and say "might as well order pizza for the rest of the week."
You skip your skincare once and abandon the routine entirely.

**This is self-sabotage with extra steps.**

Progress isn't linear. Life happens. The goal isn't perfection—it's **consistency over time**.

Missing one day means nothing. Missing one day, then letting it spiral into one week, then one month? That's the killer.

**The rule:** If you miss, just get back on track the next opportunity. No guilt, no drama. Just reset and continue.`,
      tips: [
        'One bad day is noise. One bad month is a pattern.',
        "Never miss twice in a row—that's the real rule",
        'Lower the bar if needed, but show up'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-6-money-before-basics',
      title: 'Mistake #6: Spending Money Before Basics',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.
You want Botox but you've never worn sunscreen.
You're considering hair transplants but you sleep 5 hours a night.

**You're skipping chapters, my guy.**

Here's the priority order:
1. **Free tier:** Sleep, hydration, basic hygiene, mewing, posture
2. **Low cost ($20-50/mo):** Gym, skincare basics, grooming tools
3. **Medium cost ($50-200/mo):** Supplements, better products, minoxidil
4. **High cost ($500+):** Treatments, procedures, surgery

Don't level skip. The expensive stuff doesn't work if the foundation is garbage.

Surgery on a 25% body fat face is like putting a spoiler on a Honda Civic. Fix the car first.`,
      warnings: [
        "Surgery doesn't fix lifestyle problems",
        'Get to 12% body fat before considering facial procedures'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-real-strategy',
      title: 'The Actual Strategy That Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:

**1. Accept the timeline**
You're playing a 1-2 year game minimum. Accept that now or quit.

**2. Build systems, not goals**
"I want a better jawline" is a goal. "I chew mastic gum for 20 minutes after every meal" is a system. Systems win.

**3. Track ruthlessly**
Take monthly photos. Same lighting, same angle, same expression. This is the only objective measure.

**4. Iterate slowly**
Add one new thing every 4-6 weeks. Not five things at once. You need to know what's actually working.

**5. Focus on the 80/20**
20% of actions produce 80% of results. For most guys:
- Getting lean (diet + exercise)
- Skincare (cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen)
- Grooming (hair, brows, facial hair)

**Nail these before anything else.**`,
      tips: [
        'Progress compounds over time',
        'Small daily actions beat occasional big efforts',
        'Document everything so you can see the change'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'closing',
      title: 'Lock In',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `The cope stops here. No more excuses. No more "I'll start Monday." No more blaming genetics.

You have all the information you need. This app, this guide, these tools—they're more than enough.

The only question is whether you're actually going to do the work or just read about it and go back to whatever you were doing before.

**Your move.**

Mog your past self. That's the whole game.`,
    },
  ],
};
